paginator¶

class tastypie.paginator.Paginator(request_data, objects, resource_uri=None, limit=None, offset=0, max_limit=1000, collection_name='objects')[source]¶

Bases: object

Limits result sets down to sane amounts for passing to the client.

This is used in place of Django’s Paginator due to the way pagination works. limit & offset (tastypie) are used in place of page (Django) so none of the page-related calculations are necessary.

This implementation also provides additional details like the total_count of resources seen and convenience links to the previous/next pages of data as available.

get_count()[source]¶

Returns a count of the total number of objects seen.

get_limit()[source]¶

Determines the proper maximum number of results to return.

In order of importance, it will use:

  • The user-requested limit from the GET parameters, if specified.
  • The object-level limit if specified.
  • settings.API_LIMIT_PER_PAGE if specified.

Default is 20 per page.

get_next(limit, offset, count)[source]¶

If a next page is available, will generate a URL to request that page. If not available, this returns None.

get_offset()[source]¶

Determines the proper starting offset of results to return.

It attempst to use the user-provided offset from the GET parameters, if specified. Otherwise, it falls back to the object-level offset.

Default is 0.

get_previous(limit, offset)[source]¶

If a previous page is available, will generate a URL to request that page. If not available, this returns None.

get_slice(limit, offset)[source]¶

Slices the result set to the specified limit & offset.

page()[source]¶

Generates all pertinent data about the requested page.

Handles getting the correct limit & offset, then slices off the correct set of results and returns all pertinent metadata.

resources¶

class tastypie.resources.DeclarativeMetaclass[source]¶

Bases: type

class tastypie.resources.ModelDeclarativeMetaclass[source]¶

Bases: tastypie.resources.DeclarativeMetaclass

class tastypie.resources.ModelResource(api_name=None)[source]¶

Bases: tastypie.resources.Resource

A subclass of Resource designed to work with Django’s Models.

This class will introspect a given Model and build a field list based on the fields found on the model (excluding relational fields).

Given that it is aware of Django’s ORM, it also handles the CRUD data operations of the resource.

classmethod api_field_from_django_field(f, default=<class 'tastypie.fields.CharField'>)[source]¶

Returns the field type that would likely be associated with each Django type.

apply_filters(request, applicable_filters)[source]¶

An ORM-specific implementation of apply_filters.

The default simply applies the applicable_filters as **kwargs, but should make it possible to do more advanced things.

apply_sorting(obj_list, options=None)[source]¶

Given a dictionary of options, apply some ORM-level sorting to the provided QuerySet.

Looks for the order_by key and handles either ascending (just the field name) or descending (the field name with a - in front).

The field name should be the resource field, NOT model field.

base_fields = {'resource_uri': <tastypie.fields.CharField object at 0x10b2d1190>}¶
build_filters(filters=None)[source]¶

Given a dictionary of filters, create the necessary ORM-level filters.

Keys should be resource fields, NOT model fields.

Valid values are either a list of Django filter types (i.e. ['startswith', 'exact', 'lte']), the ALL constant or the ALL_WITH_RELATIONS constant.

check_filtering(field_name, filter_type='exact', filter_bits=None)[source]¶

Given a field name, a optional filter type and an optional list of additional relations, determine if a field can be filtered on.

If a filter does not meet the needed conditions, it should raise an InvalidFilterError.

If the filter meets the conditions, a list of attribute names (not field names) will be returned.

declared_fields = {}¶
detail_uri_kwargs(bundle_or_obj)[source]¶

Given a Bundle or an object (typically a Model instance), it returns the extra kwargs needed to generate a detail URI.

By default, it uses the model’s pk in order to create the URI.

filter_value_to_python(value, field_name, filters, filter_expr, filter_type)[source]¶

Turn the string value into a python object.

classmethod get_fields(fields=None, excludes=None)[source]¶

Given any explicit fields to include and fields to exclude, add additional fields based on the associated model.

get_object_list(request)[source]¶

An ORM-specific implementation of get_object_list.

Returns a queryset that may have been limited by other overrides.

lookup_kwargs_with_identifiers(bundle, kwargs)[source]¶

Kwargs here represent uri identifiers Ex: /repos/<user_id>/<repo_name>/ We need to turn those identifiers into Python objects for generating lookup parameters that can find them in the DB

obj_create(bundle, request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

A ORM-specific implementation of obj_create.

obj_delete(request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

A ORM-specific implementation of obj_delete.

Takes optional kwargs, which are used to narrow the query to find the instance.

obj_delete_list(request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

A ORM-specific implementation of obj_delete_list.

Takes optional kwargs, which can be used to narrow the query.

obj_get(request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

A ORM-specific implementation of obj_get.

Takes optional kwargs, which are used to narrow the query to find the instance.

obj_get_list(request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

A ORM-specific implementation of obj_get_list.

Takes an optional request object, whose GET dictionary can be used to narrow the query.

obj_update(bundle, request=None, skip_errors=False, **kwargs)[source]¶

A ORM-specific implementation of obj_update.

patch_list(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

An ORM-specific implementation of patch_list.

Necessary because PATCH should be atomic (all-success or all-fail) and the only way to do this neatly is at the database level.

rollback(bundles)[source]¶

A ORM-specific implementation of rollback.

Given the list of bundles, delete all models pertaining to those bundles.

save_m2m(bundle)[source]¶

Handles the saving of related M2M data.

Due to the way Django works, the M2M data must be handled after the main instance, which is why this isn’t a part of the main save bits.

Currently slightly inefficient in that it will clear out the whole relation and recreate the related data as needed.

save_related(bundle)[source]¶

Handles the saving of related non-M2M data.

Calling assigning child.parent = parent & then calling Child.save isn’t good enough to make sure the parent is saved.

To get around this, we go through all our related fields & call save on them if they have related, non-M2M data. M2M data is handled by the ModelResource.save_m2m method.

classmethod should_skip_field(field)[source]¶

Given a Django model field, return if it should be included in the contributed ApiFields.

class tastypie.resources.NOT_AVAILABLE[source]¶
class tastypie.resources.NamespacedModelResource(api_name=None)[source]¶

Bases: tastypie.resources.ModelResource

A ModelResource subclass that respects Django namespaces.

base_fields = {'resource_uri': <tastypie.fields.CharField object at 0x10b2d1610>}¶
declared_fields = {}¶
class tastypie.resources.Resource(api_name=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Handles the data, request dispatch and responding to requests.

Serialization/deserialization is handled “at the edges” (i.e. at the beginning/end of the request/response cycle) so that everything internally is Python data structures.

This class tries to be non-model specific, so it can be hooked up to other data sources, such as search results, files, other data, etc.

alter_deserialized_detail_data(request, data)[source]¶

A hook to alter detail data just after it has been received from the user & gets deserialized.

Useful for altering the user data before any hydration is applied.

alter_deserialized_list_data(request, data)[source]¶

A hook to alter list data just after it has been received from the user & gets deserialized.

Useful for altering the user data before any hydration is applied.

alter_detail_data_to_serialize(request, data)[source]¶

A hook to alter detail data just before it gets serialized & sent to the user.

Useful for restructuring/renaming aspects of the what’s going to be sent.

Should accommodate for receiving a single bundle of data.

alter_list_data_to_serialize(request, data)[source]¶

A hook to alter list data just before it gets serialized & sent to the user.

Useful for restructuring/renaming aspects of the what’s going to be sent.

Should accommodate for a list of objects, generally also including meta data.

apply_authorization_limits(request, object_list)[source]¶

Allows the Authorization class to further limit the object list. Also a hook to customize per Resource.

apply_filters(request, applicable_filters)[source]¶

A hook to alter how the filters are applied to the object list.

This needs to be implemented at the user level.

ModelResource includes a full working version specific to Django’s Models.

apply_sorting(obj_list, options=None)[source]¶

Allows for the sorting of objects being returned.

This needs to be implemented at the user level.

ModelResource includes a full working version specific to Django’s Models.

base_fields = {'resource_uri': <tastypie.fields.CharField object at 0x10acab450>}¶
base_urls()[source]¶

The standard URLs this Resource should respond to.

build_bundle(obj=None, data=None, request=None)[source]¶

Given either an object, a data dictionary or both, builds a Bundle for use throughout the dehydrate/hydrate cycle.

If no object is provided, an empty object from Resource._meta.object_class is created so that attempts to access bundle.obj do not fail.

build_filters(filters=None)[source]¶

Allows for the filtering of applicable objects.

This needs to be implemented at the user level.’

ModelResource includes a full working version specific to Django’s Models.

build_schema()[source]¶

Returns a dictionary of all the fields on the resource and some properties about those fields.

Used by the schema/ endpoint to describe what will be available.

cached_obj_get(request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

A version of obj_get that uses the cache as a means to get commonly-accessed data faster.

cached_obj_get_list(request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

A version of obj_get_list that uses the cache as a means to get commonly-accessed data faster.

can_create()[source]¶

Checks to ensure post is within allowed_methods.

can_delete()[source]¶

Checks to ensure delete is within allowed_methods.

can_update()[source]¶

Checks to ensure put is within allowed_methods.

Used when hydrating related data.

create_response(request, data, response_class=<class 'django.http.HttpResponse'>, **response_kwargs)[source]¶

Extracts the common “which-format/serialize/return-response” cycle.

Mostly a useful shortcut/hook.

declared_fields = {}¶
dehydrate(bundle)[source]¶

A hook to allow a final manipulation of data once all fields/methods have built out the dehydrated data.

Useful if you need to access more than one dehydrated field or want to annotate on additional data.

Must return the modified bundle.

dehydrate_resource_uri(bundle)[source]¶

For the automatically included resource_uri field, dehydrate the URI for the given bundle.

Returns empty string if no URI can be generated.

delete_detail(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Destroys a single resource/object.

Calls obj_delete.

If the resource is deleted, return HttpNoContent (204 No Content). If the resource did not exist, return Http404 (404 Not Found).

delete_list(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Destroys a collection of resources/objects.

Calls obj_delete_list.

If the resources are deleted, return HttpNoContent (204 No Content).

deserialize(request, data, format='application/json')[source]¶

Given a request, data and a format, deserializes the given data.

It relies on the request properly sending a CONTENT_TYPE header, falling back to application/json if not provided.

Mostly a hook, this uses the Serializer from Resource._meta.

detail_uri_kwargs(bundle_or_obj)[source]¶

This needs to be implemented at the user level.

Given a Bundle or an object, it returns the extra kwargs needed to generate a detail URI.

ModelResource includes a full working version specific to Django’s Models.

determine_format(request)[source]¶

Used to determine the desired format.

Largely relies on tastypie.utils.mime.determine_format but here as a point of extension.

dispatch(request_type, request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Handles the common operations (allowed HTTP method, authentication, throttling, method lookup) surrounding most CRUD interactions.

dispatch_detail(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

A view for handling the various HTTP methods (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) on a single resource.

Relies on Resource.dispatch for the heavy-lifting.

dispatch_list(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

A view for handling the various HTTP methods (GET/POST/PUT/DELETE) over the entire list of resources.

Relies on Resource.dispatch for the heavy-lifting.

error_response(errors, request)[source]¶
full_dehydrate(bundle)[source]¶

Given a bundle with an object instance, extract the information from it to populate the resource.

full_hydrate(bundle)[source]¶

Given a populated bundle, distill it and turn it back into a full-fledged object instance.

generate_cache_key(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Creates a unique-enough cache key.

This is based off the current api_name/resource_name/args/kwargs.

get_bundle_detail_data(bundle)[source]¶

Convenience method to return the detail_uri_name attribute off bundle.obj.

Usually just accesses bundle.obj.pk by default.

get_detail(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Returns a single serialized resource.

Calls cached_obj_get/obj_get to provide the data, then handles that result set and serializes it.

Should return a HttpResponse (200 OK).

get_list(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Returns a serialized list of resources.

Calls obj_get_list to provide the data, then handles that result set and serializes it.

Should return a HttpResponse (200 OK).

get_multiple(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Returns a serialized list of resources based on the identifiers from the URL.

Calls obj_get to fetch only the objects requested. This method only responds to HTTP GET.

Should return a HttpResponse (200 OK).

get_object_list(request)[source]¶

A hook to allow making returning the list of available objects.

This needs to be implemented at the user level.

ModelResource includes a full working version specific to Django’s Models.

get_resource_uri(bundle_or_obj=None, url_name='api_dispatch_list')[source]¶

Handles generating a resource URI.

If the bundle_or_obj argument is not provided, it builds the URI for the list endpoint.

If the bundle_or_obj argument is provided, it builds the URI for the detail endpoint.

Return the generated URI. If that URI can not be reversed (not found in the URLconf), it will return an empty string.

get_schema(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Returns a serialized form of the schema of the resource.

Calls build_schema to generate the data. This method only responds to HTTP GET.

Should return a HttpResponse (200 OK).

get_via_uri(uri, request=None)[source]¶

This pulls apart the salient bits of the URI and populates the resource via a obj_get.

Optionally accepts a request.

If you need custom behavior based on other portions of the URI, simply override this method.

hydrate(bundle)[source]¶

A hook to allow an initial manipulation of data before all methods/fields have built out the hydrated data.

Useful if you need to access more than one hydrated field or want to annotate on additional data.

Must return the modified bundle.

hydrate_m2m(bundle)[source]¶

Populate the ManyToMany data on the instance.

is_authenticated(request)[source]¶

Handles checking if the user is authenticated and dealing with unauthenticated users.

Mostly a hook, this uses class assigned to authentication from Resource._meta.

is_authorized(request, object=None)[source]¶

Handles checking of permissions to see if the user has authorization to GET, POST, PUT, or DELETE this resource. If object is provided, the authorization backend can apply additional row-level permissions checking.

is_valid(bundle, request=None)[source]¶

Handles checking if the data provided by the user is valid.

Mostly a hook, this uses class assigned to validation from Resource._meta.

If validation fails, an error is raised with the error messages serialized inside it.

log_throttled_access(request)[source]¶

Handles the recording of the user’s access for throttling purposes.

Mostly a hook, this uses class assigned to throttle from Resource._meta.

method_check(request, allowed=None)[source]¶

Ensures that the HTTP method used on the request is allowed to be handled by the resource.

Takes an allowed parameter, which should be a list of lowercase HTTP methods to check against. Usually, this looks like:

# The most generic lookup.
self.method_check(request, self._meta.allowed_methods)

# A lookup against what's allowed for list-type methods.
self.method_check(request, self._meta.list_allowed_methods)

# A useful check when creating a new endpoint that only handles
# GET.
self.method_check(request, ['get'])
obj_create(bundle, request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Creates a new object based on the provided data.

This needs to be implemented at the user level.

ModelResource includes a full working version specific to Django’s Models.

obj_delete(request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Deletes a single object.

This needs to be implemented at the user level.

ModelResource includes a full working version specific to Django’s Models.

obj_delete_list(request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Deletes an entire list of objects.

This needs to be implemented at the user level.

ModelResource includes a full working version specific to Django’s Models.

obj_get(request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Fetches an individual object on the resource.

This needs to be implemented at the user level. If the object can not be found, this should raise a NotFound exception.

ModelResource includes a full working version specific to Django’s Models.

obj_get_list(request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Fetches the list of objects available on the resource.

This needs to be implemented at the user level.

ModelResource includes a full working version specific to Django’s Models.

obj_update(bundle, request=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Updates an existing object (or creates a new object) based on the provided data.

This needs to be implemented at the user level.

ModelResource includes a full working version specific to Django’s Models.

override_urls()[source]¶

Deprecated. Will be removed by v1.0.0. Please use prepend_urls instead.

patch_detail(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Updates a resource in-place.

Calls obj_update.

If the resource is updated, return HttpAccepted (202 Accepted). If the resource did not exist, return HttpNotFound (404 Not Found).

patch_list(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Updates a collection in-place.

The exact behavior of PATCH to a list resource is still the matter of some debate in REST circles, and the PATCH RFC isn’t standard. So the behavior this method implements (described below) is something of a stab in the dark. It’s mostly cribbed from GData, with a smattering of ActiveResource-isms and maybe even an original idea or two.

The PATCH format is one that’s similar to the response returned from a GET on a list resource:

{
  "objects": [{object}, {object}, ...],
  "deleted_objects": ["URI", "URI", "URI", ...],
}

For each object in objects:

  • If the dict does not have a resource_uri key then the item is considered “new” and is handled like a POST to the resource list.
  • If the dict has a resource_uri key and the resource_uri refers to an existing resource then the item is a update; it’s treated like a PATCH to the corresponding resource detail.
  • If the dict has a resource_uri but the resource doesn’t exist, then this is considered to be a create-via-PUT.

Each entry in deleted_objects referes to a resource URI of an existing resource to be deleted; each is handled like a DELETE to the relevent resource.

In any case:

  • If there’s a resource URI it must refer to a resource of this type. It’s an error to include a URI of a different resource.
  • PATCH is all or nothing. If a single sub-operation fails, the entire request will fail and all resources will be rolled back.
  • For PATCH to work, you must have put in your detail-allowed-methods setting.
  • To delete objects via deleted_objects in a PATCH request you must have delete in your detail-allowed-methods setting.

Substitute appropriate names for objects and deleted_objects if Meta.collection_name is set to something other than objects (default).

post_detail(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Creates a new subcollection of the resource under a resource.

This is not implemented by default because most people’s data models aren’t self-referential.

If a new resource is created, return HttpCreated (201 Created).

post_list(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Creates a new resource/object with the provided data.

Calls obj_create with the provided data and returns a response with the new resource’s location.

If a new resource is created, return HttpCreated (201 Created). If Meta.always_return_data = True, there will be a populated body of serialized data.

prepend_urls()[source]¶

A hook for adding your own URLs or matching before the default URLs.

put_detail(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Either updates an existing resource or creates a new one with the provided data.

Calls obj_update with the provided data first, but falls back to obj_create if the object does not already exist.

If a new resource is created, return HttpCreated (201 Created). If Meta.always_return_data = True, there will be a populated body of serialized data.

If an existing resource is modified and Meta.always_return_data = False (default), return HttpNoContent (204 No Content). If an existing resource is modified and Meta.always_return_data = True, return HttpAccepted (202 Accepted).

put_list(request, **kwargs)[source]¶

Replaces a collection of resources with another collection.

Calls delete_list to clear out the collection then obj_create with the provided the data to create the new collection.

Return HttpNoContent (204 No Content) if Meta.always_return_data = False (default).

Return HttpAccepted (202 Accepted) if Meta.always_return_data = True.

remove_api_resource_names(url_dict)[source]¶

Given a dictionary of regex matches from a URLconf, removes api_name and/or resource_name if found.

This is useful for converting URLconf matches into something suitable for data lookup. For example:

Model.objects.filter(**self.remove_api_resource_names(matches))
resource_uri_kwargs(bundle_or_obj=None)[source]¶

Builds a dictionary of kwargs to help generate URIs.

Automatically provides the Resource.Meta.resource_name (and optionally the Resource.Meta.api_name if populated by an Api object).

If the bundle_or_obj argument is provided, it calls Resource.detail_uri_kwargs for additional bits to create

rollback(bundles)[source]¶

Given the list of bundles, delete all objects pertaining to those bundles.

This needs to be implemented at the user level. No exceptions should be raised if possible.

ModelResource includes a full working version specific to Django’s Models.

serialize(request, data, format, options=None)[source]¶

Given a request, data and a desired format, produces a serialized version suitable for transfer over the wire.

Mostly a hook, this uses the Serializer from Resource._meta.

throttle_check(request)[source]¶

Handles checking if the user should be throttled.

Mostly a hook, this uses class assigned to throttle from Resource._meta.

update_in_place(request, original_bundle, new_data)[source]¶

Update the object in original_bundle in-place using new_data.

urls[source]¶

The endpoints this Resource responds to.

Mostly a standard URLconf, this is suitable for either automatic use when registered with an Api class or for including directly in a URLconf should you choose to.

wrap_view(view)[source]¶

Wraps methods so they can be called in a more functional way as well as handling exceptions better.

Note that if BadRequest or an exception with a response attr are seen, there is special handling to either present a message back to the user or return the response traveling with the exception.

serializers¶

class tastypie.serializers.Serializer(formats=None, content_types=None, datetime_formatting=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A swappable class for serialization.

This handles most types of data as well as the following output formats:

* json
* jsonp
* xml
* yaml
* html
* plist (see http://explorapp.com/biplist/)

It was designed to make changing behavior easy, either by overridding the various format methods (i.e. to_json), by changing the formats/content_types options or by altering the other hook methods.

content_types = {'xml': 'application/xml', 'yaml': 'text/yaml', 'json': 'application/json', 'html': 'text/html', 'jsonp': 'text/javascript', 'plist': 'application/x-plist'}¶
deserialize(content, format='application/json')[source]¶

Given some data and a format, calls the correct method to deserialize the data and returns the result.

format_date(data)[source]¶

A hook to control how dates are formatted.

Can be overridden at the Serializer level (datetime_formatting) or globally (via settings.TASTYPIE_DATETIME_FORMATTING).

Default is iso-8601, which looks like “2010-12-16”.

format_datetime(data)[source]¶

A hook to control how datetimes are formatted.

Can be overridden at the Serializer level (datetime_formatting) or globally (via settings.TASTYPIE_DATETIME_FORMATTING).

Default is iso-8601, which looks like “2010-12-16T03:02:14”.

format_time(data)[source]¶

A hook to control how times are formatted.

Can be overridden at the Serializer level (datetime_formatting) or globally (via settings.TASTYPIE_DATETIME_FORMATTING).

Default is iso-8601, which looks like “03:02:14”.

formats = ['json', 'jsonp', 'xml', 'yaml', 'html', 'plist']¶
from_etree(data)[source]¶

Not the smartest deserializer on the planet. At the request level, it first tries to output the deserialized subelement called “object” or “objects” and falls back to deserializing based on hinted types in the XML element attribute “type”.

from_html(content)[source]¶

Reserved for future usage.

The desire is to handle form-based (maybe Javascript?) input, making an API available to a browser. This is on the TODO list but not currently implemented.

from_json(content)[source]¶

Given some JSON data, returns a Python dictionary of the decoded data.

from_plist(content)[source]¶

Given some binary plist data, returns a Python dictionary of the decoded data.

from_xml(content)[source]¶

Given some XML data, returns a Python dictionary of the decoded data.

from_yaml(content)[source]¶

Given some YAML data, returns a Python dictionary of the decoded data.

get_mime_for_format(format)[source]¶

Given a format, attempts to determine the correct MIME type.

If not available on the current Serializer, returns application/json by default.

serialize(bundle, format='application/json', options={})[source]¶

Given some data and a format, calls the correct method to serialize the data and returns the result.

to_etree(data, options=None, name=None, depth=0)[source]¶

Given some data, converts that data to an etree.Element suitable for use in the XML output.

to_html(data, options=None)[source]¶

Reserved for future usage.

The desire is to provide HTML output of a resource, making an API available to a browser. This is on the TODO list but not currently implemented.

to_json(data, options=None)[source]¶

Given some Python data, produces JSON output.

to_jsonp(data, options=None)[source]¶

Given some Python data, produces JSON output wrapped in the provided callback.

Due to a difference between JSON and Javascript, two newline characters, u2028 and u2029, need to be escaped. See http://timelessrepo.com/json-isnt-a-javascript-subset for details.

to_plist(data, options=None)[source]¶

Given some Python data, produces binary plist output.

to_simple(data, options)[source]¶

For a piece of data, attempts to recognize it and provide a simplified form of something complex.

This brings complex Python data structures down to native types of the serialization format(s).

to_xml(data, options=None)[source]¶

Given some Python data, produces XML output.

to_yaml(data, options=None)[source]¶

Given some Python data, produces YAML output.

tastypie.serializers.get_type_string(data)[source]¶

Translates a Python data type into a string format.

Bases: django.test.testcases.TestCase

A useful base class for the start of testing Tastypie APIs.

assertHttpAccepted(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning either a HTTP 202 or a HTTP 204.

assertHttpApplicationError(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 500.

assertHttpBadRequest(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 400.

assertHttpConflict(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 409.

assertHttpCreated(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 201.

assertHttpForbidden(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 403.

assertHttpGone(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 410.

assertHttpMethodNotAllowed(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 405.

assertHttpMultipleChoices(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 300.

assertHttpNotFound(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 404.

assertHttpNotImplemented(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 501.

assertHttpNotModified(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 304.

assertHttpOK(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 200.

assertHttpSeeOther(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 303.

assertHttpTooManyRequests(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 429.

assertHttpUnauthorized(resp)[source]¶

Ensures the response is returning a HTTP 401.

assertKeys(data, expected)[source]¶

This method ensures that the keys of the data match up to the keys of expected.

It covers the (extremely) common case where you want to make sure the keys of a response match up to what is expected. This is typically less fragile than testing the full structure, which can be prone to data changes.

assertValidJSON(data)[source]¶

Given the provided data as a string, ensures that it is valid JSON & can be loaded properly.

assertValidJSONResponse(resp)[source]¶

Given a HttpResponse coming back from using the client, assert that you get back:

  • An HTTP 200
  • The correct content-type (application/json)
  • The content is valid JSON
assertValidPlist(data)[source]¶

Given the provided data as a string, ensures that it is valid binary plist & can be loaded properly.

assertValidPlistResponse(resp)[source]¶

Given a HttpResponse coming back from using the client, assert that you get back:

  • An HTTP 200
  • The correct content-type (application/x-plist)
  • The content is valid binary plist data
assertValidXML(data)[source]¶

Given the provided data as a string, ensures that it is valid XML & can be loaded properly.

assertValidXMLResponse(resp)[source]¶

Given a HttpResponse coming back from using the client, assert that you get back:

  • An HTTP 200
  • The correct content-type (application/xml)
  • The content is valid XML
assertValidYAML(data)[source]¶

Given the provided data as a string, ensures that it is valid YAML & can be loaded properly.

assertValidYAMLResponse(resp)[source]¶

Given a HttpResponse coming back from using the client, assert that you get back:

  • An HTTP 200
  • The correct content-type (text/yaml)
  • The content is valid YAML
create_apikey(username, api_key)[source]¶

Creates & returns the HTTP Authorization header for use with ApiKeyAuthentication.

create_basic(username, password)[source]¶

Creates & returns the HTTP Authorization header for use with BASIC Auth.

create_digest(username, api_key, method, uri)[source]¶

Creates & returns the HTTP Authorization header for use with Digest Auth.

create_oauth(user)[source]¶

Creates & returns the HTTP Authorization header for use with Oauth.

deserialize(resp)[source]¶

Given a HttpResponse coming back from using the client, this method checks the Content-Type header & attempts to deserialize the data based on that.

It returns a Python datastructure (typically a dict) of the serialized data.

get_credentials()[source]¶

A convenience method for the user as a way to shorten up the often repetitious calls to create the same authentication.

Raises NotImplementedError by default.

Usage:

class MyResourceTestCase(ResourceTestCase):
    def get_credentials(self):
        return self.create_basic('daniel', 'pass')

    # Then the usual tests...
serialize(data, format='application/json')[source]¶

Given a Python datastructure (typically a dict) & a desired content-type, this method will return a serialized string of that data.

setUp()[source]¶
class tastypie.test.TestApiClient(serializer=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

delete(uri, format='json', data=None, authentication=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Performs a simulated DELETE request to the provided URI.

Optionally accepts a data kwarg, which in the case of DELETE, lets you send along DELETE parameters. This is useful when testing filtering or other things that read off the DELETE params. Example:

from tastypie.test import TestApiClient
client = TestApiClient()

response = client.delete('/api/v1/entry/1/', data={'format': 'json'})

Optionally accepts an authentication kwarg, which should be an HTTP header with the correct authentication data already setup.

All other **kwargs passed in get passed through to the Django TestClient. See https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/testing/#module-django.test.client for details.

get(uri, format='json', data=None, authentication=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Performs a simulated GET request to the provided URI.

Optionally accepts a data kwarg, which in the case of GET, lets you send along GET parameters. This is useful when testing filtering or other things that read off the GET params. Example:

from tastypie.test import TestApiClient
client = TestApiClient()

response = client.get('/api/v1/entry/1/', data={'format': 'json', 'title__startswith': 'a', 'limit': 20, 'offset': 60})

Optionally accepts an authentication kwarg, which should be an HTTP header with the correct authentication data already setup.

All other **kwargs passed in get passed through to the Django TestClient. See https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/testing/#module-django.test.client for details.

get_content_type(short_format)[source]¶

Given a short name (such as json or xml), returns the full content-type for it (application/json or application/xml in this case).

patch(uri, format='json', data=None, authentication=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Performs a simulated PATCH request to the provided URI.

Optionally accepts a data kwarg. Unlike GET, in PATCH the data gets serialized & sent as the body instead of becoming part of the URI. Example:

from tastypie.test import TestApiClient
client = TestApiClient()

response = client.patch('/api/v1/entry/1/', data={
    'created': '2012-05-01T20:02:36',
    'slug': 'another-post',
    'title': 'Another Post',
    'user': '/api/v1/user/1/',
})

Optionally accepts an authentication kwarg, which should be an HTTP header with the correct authentication data already setup.

All other **kwargs passed in get passed through to the Django TestClient. See https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/testing/#module-django.test.client for details.

post(uri, format='json', data=None, authentication=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Performs a simulated POST request to the provided URI.

Optionally accepts a data kwarg. Unlike GET, in POST the data gets serialized & sent as the body instead of becoming part of the URI. Example:

from tastypie.test import TestApiClient
client = TestApiClient()

response = client.post('/api/v1/entry/', data={
    'created': '2012-05-01T20:02:36',
    'slug': 'another-post',
    'title': 'Another Post',
    'user': '/api/v1/user/1/',
})

Optionally accepts an authentication kwarg, which should be an HTTP header with the correct authentication data already setup.

All other **kwargs passed in get passed through to the Django TestClient. See https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/testing/#module-django.test.client for details.

put(uri, format='json', data=None, authentication=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Performs a simulated PUT request to the provided URI.

Optionally accepts a data kwarg. Unlike GET, in PUT the data gets serialized & sent as the body instead of becoming part of the URI. Example:

from tastypie.test import TestApiClient
client = TestApiClient()

response = client.put('/api/v1/entry/1/', data={
    'created': '2012-05-01T20:02:36',
    'slug': 'another-post',
    'title': 'Another Post',
    'user': '/api/v1/user/1/',
})

Optionally accepts an authentication kwarg, which should be an HTTP header with the correct authentication data already setup.

All other **kwargs passed in get passed through to the Django TestClient. See https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/dev/topics/testing/#module-django.test.client for details.

throttle¶

class tastypie.throttle.BaseThrottle(throttle_at=150, timeframe=3600, expiration=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A simplified, swappable base class for throttling.

Does nothing save for simulating the throttling API and implementing some common bits for the subclasses.

Accepts a number of optional kwargs:

* ``throttle_at`` - the number of requests at which the user should
  be throttled. Default is 150 requests.
* ``timeframe`` - the length of time (in seconds) in which the user
  make up to the ``throttle_at`` requests. Default is 3600 seconds (
  1 hour).
* ``expiration`` - the length of time to retain the times the user
  has accessed the api in the cache. Default is 604800 (1 week).
accessed(identifier, **kwargs)[source]¶

Handles recording the user’s access.

Does nothing in this implementation.

convert_identifier_to_key(identifier)[source]¶

Takes an identifier (like a username or IP address) and converts it into a key usable by the cache system.

should_be_throttled(identifier, **kwargs)[source]¶

Returns whether or not the user has exceeded their throttle limit.

Always returns False, as this implementation does not actually throttle the user.

class tastypie.throttle.CacheDBThrottle(throttle_at=150, timeframe=3600, expiration=None)[source]¶

Bases: tastypie.throttle.CacheThrottle

A throttling mechanism that uses the cache for actual throttling but writes-through to the database.

This is useful for tracking/aggregating usage through time, to possibly build a statistics interface or a billing mechanism.

accessed(identifier, **kwargs)[source]¶

Handles recording the user’s access.

Does everything the CacheThrottle class does, plus logs the access within the database using the ApiAccess model.

class tastypie.throttle.CacheThrottle(throttle_at=150, timeframe=3600, expiration=None)[source]¶

Bases: tastypie.throttle.BaseThrottle

A throttling mechanism that uses just the cache.

accessed(identifier, **kwargs)[source]¶

Handles recording the user’s access.

Stores the current timestamp in the “accesses” list within the cache.

should_be_throttled(identifier, **kwargs)[source]¶

Returns whether or not the user has exceeded their throttle limit.

Maintains a list of timestamps when the user accessed the api within the cache.

Returns False if the user should NOT be throttled or True if the user should be throttled.

validation¶

class tastypie.validation.CleanedDataFormValidation(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: tastypie.validation.FormValidation

A validation class that uses a Django Form to validate the data.

This class ALTERS data sent by the user!!!

This class requires a form_class argument, which should be a Django Form (or ModelForm, though save will never be called) class. This form will be used to validate the data in bundle.data.

is_valid(bundle, request=None)[source]¶

Checks ``bundle.data``to ensure it is valid & replaces it with the cleaned results.

If the form is valid, an empty list (all valid) will be returned. If not, a list of errors will be returned.

class tastypie.validation.FormValidation(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: tastypie.validation.Validation

A validation class that uses a Django Form to validate the data.

This class DOES NOT alter the data sent, only verifies it. If you want to alter the data, please use the CleanedDataFormValidation class instead.

This class requires a form_class argument, which should be a Django Form (or ModelForm, though save will never be called) class. This form will be used to validate the data in bundle.data.

form_args(bundle)[source]¶
is_valid(bundle, request=None)[source]¶

Performs a check on ``bundle.data``to ensure it is valid.

If the form is valid, an empty list (all valid) will be returned. If not, a list of errors will be returned.

class tastypie.validation.Validation(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

A basic validation stub that does no validation.

is_valid(bundle, request=None)[source]¶

Performs a check on the data within the bundle (and optionally the request) to ensure it is valid.

Should return a dictionary of error messages. If the dictionary has zero items, the data is considered valid. If there are errors, keys in the dictionary should be field names and the values should be a list of errors, even if there is only one.

Replace this with more appropriate tests for your application.

class django.contrib.sites.models.RequestSite(request)[source]¶

Bases: object

A class that shares the primary interface of Site (i.e., it has domain and name attributes) but gets its data from a Django HttpRequest object rather than from a database.

The save() and delete() methods raise NotImplementedError.

class django.contrib.sites.models.SiteManager[source]¶

clear_cache()[source]¶

Clears the Site object cache.

get_current()[source]¶

Returns the current Site based on the SITE_ID in the project’s settings. The Site object is cached the first time it’s retrieved from the database.

django.contrib.sites.models.get_current_site(request)[source]¶

Checks if contrib.sites is installed and returns either the current Site object or a RequestSite object based on the request.

class haystack.fields.FacetField(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: haystack.fields.SearchField

FacetField is slightly different than the other fields because it can work in conjunction with other fields as its data source.

Accepts an optional facet_for kwarg, which should be the field name (not index_fieldname) of the field it should pull data from.

class haystack.fields.SearchField(model_attr=None, use_template=False, template_name=None, document=False, indexed=True, stored=True, faceted=False, default=<class haystack.fields.NOT_PROVIDED at 0x10d210738>, null=False, index_fieldname=None, facet_class=None, boost=1.0, weight=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

The base implementation of a search field.

convert(value)[source]¶

Handles conversion between the data found and the type of the field.

Extending classes should override this method and provide correct data coercion.

default[source]¶

Returns the default value for the field.

field_type = None¶
has_default()[source]¶

Returns a boolean of whether this field has a default value.

prepare(obj)[source]¶

Takes data from the provided object and prepares it for storage in the index.

prepare_template(obj)[source]¶

Flattens an object for indexing.

This loads a template (search/indexes/{app_label}/{model_name}_{field_name}.txt) and returns the result of rendering that template. object will be in its context.

media¶
no_query_found()[source]¶

Determines the behavior when no query was found.

By default, no results are returned (EmptySearchQuerySet).

Should you want to show all results, override this method in your own SearchForm subclass and do return self.searchqueryset.all().

indexes¶

class haystack.indexes.BasicSearchIndex[source]¶

Bases: haystack.indexes.SearchIndex

fields = {'text': <haystack.fields.CharField object at 0x10d458850>}¶
class haystack.indexes.DeclarativeMetaclass[source]¶

Bases: type

class haystack.indexes.ModelSearchIndex(extra_field_kwargs=None)[source]¶

Bases: haystack.indexes.SearchIndex

Introspects the model assigned to it and generates a SearchIndex based on the fields of that model.

In addition, it adds a text field that is the document=True field and has use_template=True option set, just like the BasicSearchIndex.

Usage of this class might result in inferior SearchIndex objects, which can directly affect your search results. Use this to establish basic functionality and move to custom SearchIndex objects for better control.

At this time, it does not handle related fields.

fields = {'text': <haystack.fields.CharField object at 0x10d458790>}¶
fields_to_skip = ('id', 'django_ct', 'django_id', 'content', 'text')¶
get_fields(fields=None, excludes=None)[source]¶

Given any explicit fields to include and fields to exclude, add additional fields based on the associated model.

get_index_fieldname(f)[source]¶

Given a Django field, return the appropriate index fieldname.

get_model()[source]¶
should_skip_field(field)[source]¶

Given a Django model field, return if it should be included in the contributed SearchFields.

class haystack.indexes.SearchIndex[source]¶

Bases: thread._local

Base class for building indexes.

An example might look like this:

import datetime
from haystack import indexes
from myapp.models import Note

class NoteIndex(indexes.SearchIndex, indexes.Indexable):
    text = indexes.CharField(document=True, use_template=True)
    author = indexes.CharField(model_attr='user')
    pub_date = indexes.DateTimeField(model_attr='pub_date')

    def get_model(self):
        return Note

    def index_queryset(self, using=None):
        return self.get_model().objects.filter(pub_date__lte=datetime.datetime.now())
build_queryset(using=None, start_date=None, end_date=None)[source]¶

Get the default QuerySet to index when doing an index update.

Subclasses can override this method to take into account related model modification times.

The default is to use SearchIndex.index_queryset and filter based on SearchIndex.get_updated_field

clear(using=None)[source]¶

Clears the entire index.

If using is provided, it specifies which connection should be used. Default relies on the routers to decide which backend should be used.

fields = {}¶
full_prepare(obj)[source]¶
get_content_field()[source]¶

Returns the field that supplies the primary document to be indexed.

get_field_weights()[source]¶

Returns a dict of fields with weight values

get_model()[source]¶

Should return the Model class (not an instance) that the rest of the SearchIndex should use.

This method is required & you must override it to return the correct class.

get_updated_field()[source]¶

Get the field name that represents the updated date for the model.

If specified, this is used by the reindex command to filter out results from the QuerySet, enabling you to reindex only recent records. This method should either return None (reindex everything always) or a string of the Model’s DateField/DateTimeField name.

index_queryset(using=None)[source]¶

Get the default QuerySet to index when doing a full update.

Subclasses can override this method to avoid indexing certain objects.

load_all_queryset()[source]¶

Provides the ability to override how objects get loaded in conjunction with SearchQuerySet.load_all.

This is useful for post-processing the results from the query, enabling things like adding select_related or filtering certain data.

By default, returns all() on the model’s default manager.

prepare(obj)[source]¶

Fetches and adds/alters data before indexing.

read_queryset(using=None)[source]¶

Get the default QuerySet for read actions.

Subclasses can override this method to work with other managers. Useful when working with default managers that filter some objects.

reindex(using=None)[source]¶

Completely clear the index for this model and rebuild it.

If using is provided, it specifies which connection should be used. Default relies on the routers to decide which backend should be used.

remove_object(instance, using=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Remove an object from the index. Attached to the class’s post-delete hook.

If using is provided, it specifies which connection should be used. Default relies on the routers to decide which backend should be used.

should_update(instance, **kwargs)[source]¶

Determine if an object should be updated in the index.

It’s useful to override this when an object may save frequently and cause excessive reindexing. You should check conditions on the instance and return False if it is not to be indexed.

By default, returns True (always reindex).

update(using=None)[source]¶

Updates the entire index.

If using is provided, it specifies which connection should be used. Default relies on the routers to decide which backend should be used.

update_object(instance, using=None, **kwargs)[source]¶

Update the index for a single object. Attached to the class’s post-save hook.

If using is provided, it specifies which connection should be used. Default relies on the routers to decide which backend should be used.

haystack.indexes.index_field_from_django_field(f, default=<class 'haystack.fields.CharField'>)[source]¶

Returns the Haystack field type that would likely be associated with each Django type.

class haystack.inputs.AutoQuery(query_string, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: haystack.inputs.BaseInput

A convenience class that handles common user queries.

In addition to cleaning all tokens, it handles double quote bits as exact matches & terms with ‘-‘ in front as NOT queries.

models¶

class haystack.models.SearchResult(app_label, model_name, pk, score, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

A single search result. The actual object is loaded lazily by accessing object; until then this object only stores the model, pk, and score.

Note that iterating over SearchResults and getting the object for each result will do O(N) database queries, which may not fit your needs for performance.

content_type()[source]¶

Returns the content type for the result’s model instance.

distance¶
get_additional_fields()[source]¶

Returns a dictionary of all of the fields from the raw result.

Useful for serializing results. Only returns what was seen from the search engine, so it may have extra fields Haystack’s indexes aren’t aware of.

get_stored_fields()[source]¶

Returns a dictionary of all of the stored fields from the SearchIndex.

Useful for serializing results. Only returns the fields Haystack’s indexes are aware of as being ‘stored’.

model¶
object¶
searchindex¶
verbose_name¶
verbose_name_plural¶

query¶

class haystack.query.EmptySearchQuerySet(using=None, query=None)[source]¶

Bases: haystack.query.SearchQuerySet

A stubbed SearchQuerySet that behaves as normal but always returns no results.

facet_counts()[source]¶
class haystack.query.RelatedSearchQuerySet(using=None, query=None)[source]¶

Bases: haystack.query.SearchQuerySet

A variant of the SearchQuerySet that can handle `load_all_queryset`s.

This is predominantly different in the _fill_cache method, as it is far less efficient but needs to fill the cache before it to maintain consistency.

load_all_queryset(model, queryset)[source]¶

Allows for specifying a custom QuerySet that changes how load_all will fetch records for the provided model.

This is useful for post-processing the results from the query, enabling things like adding select_related or filtering certain data.

class haystack.query.SearchQuerySet(using=None, query=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

Provides a way to specify search parameters and lazily load results.

Supports chaining (a la QuerySet) to narrow the search.

all()[source]¶

Returns all results for the query.

auto_query(query_string, fieldname='content')[source]¶

Performs a best guess constructing the search query.

This method is somewhat naive but works well enough for the simple, common cases.

autocomplete(**kwargs)[source]¶

A shortcut method to perform an autocomplete search.

Must be run against fields that are either NgramField or EdgeNgramField.

best_match()[source]¶

Returns the best/top search result that matches the query.

boost(term, boost)[source]¶

Boosts a certain aspect of the query.

count()[source]¶

Returns the total number of matching results.

date_facet(field, start_date, end_date, gap_by, gap_amount=1)[source]¶

Adds faceting to a query for the provided field by date.

distance(field, point)[source]¶

Spatial: Denotes results must have distance measurements from the provided point.

dwithin(field, point, distance)[source]¶

Spatial: Adds a distance-based search to the query.

exclude(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Narrows the search by ensuring certain attributes are not included.

facet(field)[source]¶

Adds faceting to a query for the provided field.

facet_counts()[source]¶

Returns the facet counts found by the query.

This will cause the query to execute and should generally be used when presenting the data.

filter(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Narrows the search based on certain attributes and the default operator.

filter_and(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Narrows the search by looking for (and including) certain attributes.

filter_or(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Narrows the search by ensuring certain attributes are not included.

highlight()[source]¶

Adds highlighting to the results.

latest(date_field)[source]¶

Returns the most recent search result that matches the query.

load_all()[source]¶

Efficiently populates the objects in the search results.

models(*models)[source]¶

Accepts an arbitrary number of Model classes to include in the search.

more_like_this(model_instance)[source]¶

Finds similar results to the object passed in.

narrow(query)[source]¶

Pushes existing facet choices into the search.

none()[source]¶

Returns an empty result list for the query.

order_by(*args)[source]¶

Alters the order in which the results should appear.

order_by_distance(**kwargs)[source]¶

Alters the order in which the results should appear.

post_process_results(results)[source]¶
query_facet(field, query)[source]¶

Adds faceting to a query for the provided field with a custom query.

raw_search(query_string, **kwargs)[source]¶

Passes a raw query directly to the backend.

result_class(klass)[source]¶

Allows specifying a different class to use for results.

Overrides any previous usages. If None is provided, Haystack will revert back to the default SearchResult object.

spelling_suggestion(preferred_query=None)[source]¶

Returns the spelling suggestion found by the query.

To work, you must set INCLUDE_SPELLING within your connection’s settings dictionary to True. Otherwise, None will be returned.

This will cause the query to execute and should generally be used when presenting the data.

using(connection_name)[source]¶

Allows switching which connection the SearchQuerySet uses to search in.

values(*fields)[source]¶

Returns a list of dictionaries, each containing the key/value pairs for the result, exactly like Django’s ValuesQuerySet.

values_list(*fields, **kwargs)[source]¶

Returns a list of field values as tuples, exactly like Django’s QuerySet.values.

Optionally accepts a flat=True kwarg, which in the case of a single field being provided, will return a flat list of that field rather than a list of tuples.

within(field, point_1, point_2)[source]¶

Spatial: Adds a bounding box search to the query.

class haystack.query.ValuesListSearchQuerySet(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: haystack.query.SearchQuerySet

A SearchQuerySet which returns a list of field values as tuples, exactly like Django’s ValuesListQuerySet.

post_process_results(results)[source]¶
class haystack.query.ValuesSearchQuerySet(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: haystack.query.ValuesListSearchQuerySet

A SearchQuerySet which returns a list of dictionaries, each containing the key/value pairs for the result, exactly like Django’s ValuesQuerySet.

post_process_results(results)[source]¶

signals¶

class haystack.signals.BaseSignalProcessor(connections, connection_router)[source]¶

Bases: object

A convenient way to attach Haystack to Django’s signals & cause things to index.

By default, does nothing with signals but provides underlying functionality.

handle_delete(sender, instance, **kwargs)[source]¶

Given an individual model instance, determine which backends the delete should be sent to & delete the object on those backends.

handle_save(sender, instance, **kwargs)[source]¶

Given an individual model instance, determine which backends the update should be sent to & update the object on those backends.

setup()[source]¶

A hook for setting up anything necessary for handle_save/handle_delete to be executed.

Default behavior is to do nothing (pass).

teardown()[source]¶

A hook for tearing down anything necessary for handle_save/handle_delete to no longer be executed.

Default behavior is to do nothing (pass).

class haystack.signals.RealtimeSignalProcessor(connections, connection_router)[source]¶

Bases: haystack.signals.BaseSignalProcessor

Bases: haystack.views.SearchView

class haystack.views.SearchView(template=None, load_all=True, form_class=None, searchqueryset=None, context_class=<class 'django.template.context.RequestContext'>, results_per_page=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

build_form(form_kwargs=None)[source]¶

Instantiates the form the class should use to process the search query.

build_page()[source]¶

Paginates the results appropriately.

In case someone does not want to use Django’s built-in pagination, it should be a simple matter to override this method to do what they would like.

create_response()[source]¶

Generates the actual HttpResponse to send back to the user.

extra_context()[source]¶

Allows the addition of more context variables as needed.

Must return a dictionary.

form = None¶
get_query()[source]¶

Returns the query provided by the user.

Returns an empty string if the query is invalid.

get_results()[source]¶

Fetches the results via the form.

Returns an empty list if there’s no query to search with.

query = ''¶
request = None¶
results = []¶
results_per_page = 20¶
template = 'search/search.html'¶
haystack.views.basic_search(request, template='search/search.html', load_all=True, form_class=<class 'haystack.forms.ModelSearchForm'>, searchqueryset=None, context_class=<class 'django.template.context.RequestContext'>, extra_context=None, results_per_page=None)[source]¶

A more traditional view that also demonstrate an alternative way to use Haystack.

Useful as an example of for basing heavily custom views off of.

Also has the benefit of thread-safety, which the SearchView class may not be.

Template:: search/search.html Context:

* form
  An instance of the ``form_class``. (default: ``ModelSearchForm``)
* page
  The current page of search results.
* paginator
  A paginator instance for the results.
* query
  The query received by the form.
haystack.views.search_view_factory(view_class=<class 'haystack.views.SearchView'>, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

class eav.admin.BaseEntityAdmin(model, admin_site)[source]¶

Bases: django.contrib.admin.options.ModelAdmin

media¶
render_change_form(request, context, add=False, change=False, form_url='', obj=None)[source]¶

Wrapper for ModelAdmin.render_change_form. Replaces standard static AdminForm with an EAV-friendly one. The point is that our form generates fields dynamically and fieldsets must be inferred from a prepared and validated form instance, not just the form class. Django does not seem to provide hooks for this purpose, so we simply wrap the view and substitute some data.

class eav.admin.BaseEntityInline(parent_model, admin_site)[source]¶

Bases: django.contrib.admin.options.InlineModelAdmin

Inline model admin that works correctly with EAV attributes. You should mix in the standard StackedInline or TabularInline classes in order to define formset representation, e.g.:

class ItemInline(BaseEntityInline, StackedInline):
    model = Item
    form = forms.ItemForm
formset¶

alias of BaseEntityInlineFormSet

class eav.fields.EavDatatypeField(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.fields.CharField

The datatype field used by Attribute

validate(value, instance)[source]¶

Raise ValidationError if they try to change the datatype of an Attribute that is already used by Value objects.

class eav.fields.EavSlugField(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.fields.SlugField

The slug field used by Attribute

static create_slug_from_name(name)[source]¶

Creates a slug based on the name

validate(value, instance)[source]¶

Slugs are used to convert the Python attribute name to a database lookup and vice versa. We need it to be a valid Python identifier. We don’t want it to start with a ‘_’, underscore will be used var variables we don’t want to be saved in db.

forms¶

forms¶

The forms used for admin integration

Classes¶
class eav.forms.BaseDynamicEntityForm(data=None, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.forms.models.ModelForm

ModelForm for entity with support for EAV attributes. Form fields are created on the fly depending on Schema defined for given entity instance. If no schema is defined (i.e. the entity instance has not been saved yet), only static fields are used. However, on form validation the schema will be retrieved and EAV fields dynamically added to the form, so when the validation is actually done, all EAV fields are present in it (unless Rubric is not defined).

FIELD_CLASSES = {'enum': <class 'django.forms.fields.ChoiceField'>, 'int': <class 'django.forms.fields.IntegerField'>, 'text': <class 'django.forms.fields.CharField'>, 'float': <class 'django.forms.fields.FloatField'>, 'bool': <class 'django.forms.fields.BooleanField'>, 'date': <class 'django.forms.fields.DateTimeField'>}¶
base_fields = {}¶
declared_fields = {}¶
media¶
save(commit=True)[source]¶

Saves this form‘s cleaned_data into model instance self.instance and related EAV attributes.

Returns instance.

managers¶

managers¶

Contains the custom manager used by entities registered with eav.

Functions and Classes¶
class eav.managers.EntityManager[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.manager.Manager

Our custom manager, overriding models.Manager

create(**kwargs)[source]¶

Parse eav attributes out of kwargs, then try to create and save the object, then assign and save it’s eav attributes.

exclude(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Pass args and kwargs through eav_filter(), then pass to the models.Manager exclude method.

filter(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Pass args and kwargs through eav_filter(), then pass to the models.Manager filter method.

get(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Pass args and kwargs through eav_filter(), then pass to the models.Manager get method.

get_or_create(**kwargs)[source]¶

Reproduces the behavior of get_or_create, eav friendly.

eav.managers.eav_filter(func)[source]¶

Decorator used to wrap filter and exlclude methods. Passes args through expand_q_filters and kwargs through expand_eav_filter. Returns the called function (filter or exclude)

eav.managers.expand_eav_filter(model_cls, key, value)[source]¶

Accepts a model class and a key, value. Recurisively replaces any eav filter with a subquery.

For example:

key = 'eav__height'
value = 5

Would return:

key = 'eav_values__in'
value = Values.objects.filter(value_int=5, attribute__slug='height')
eav.managers.expand_q_filters(q, root_cls)[source]¶

Takes a Q object and a model class. Recursivley passes each filter / value in the Q object tree leaf nodes through expand_eav_filter

models¶

models¶

This module defines the four concrete, non-abstract models:

  • Value
  • Attribute
  • EnumValue
  • EnumGroup

Along with the Entity helper class.

Classes¶
class eav.models.Attribute(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

Putting the A in EAV. This holds the attributes, or concepts. Examples of possible Attributes: color, height, weight, number of children, number of patients, has fever?, etc...

Each attribute has a name, and a description, along with a slug that must be unique. If you don’t provide a slug, a default slug (derived from name), will be created.

The required field is a boolean that indicates whether this EAV attribute is required for entities to which it applies. It defaults to False.

Warning

Just like a normal model field that is required, you will not be able to save or create any entity object for which this attribute applies, without first setting this EAV attribute.

There are 7 possible values for datatype:

  • int (TYPE_INT)
  • float (TYPE_FLOAT)
  • text (TYPE_TEXT)
  • date (TYPE_DATE)
  • bool (TYPE_BOOLEAN)
  • object (TYPE_OBJECT)
  • enum (TYPE_ENUM)

Examples:

>>> Attribute.objects.create(name='Height', datatype=Attribute.TYPE_INT)
<Attribute: Height (Integer)>

>>> Attribute.objects.create(name='Color', datatype=Attribute.TYPE_TEXT)
<Attribute: Color (Text)>

>>> yes = EnumValue.objects.create(value='yes')
>>> no = EnumValue.objects.create(value='no')
>>> unkown = EnumValue.objects.create(value='unkown')
>>> ynu = EnumGroup.objects.create(name='Yes / No / Unkown')
>>> ynu.enums.add(yes, no, unkown)
>>> Atrribute.objects.create(name='Has Fever?',
...                          datatype=Attribute.TYPE_ENUM,
...                          enum_group=ynu)
<Attribute: Has Fever? (Multiple Choice)>

Warning

Once an Attribute has been used by an entity, you can not change it’s datatype.

DATATYPE_CHOICES = (('text', <django.utils.functional.__proxy__ object at 0x1060b5050>), ('float', <django.utils.functional.__proxy__ object at 0x1060b5110>), ('int', <django.utils.functional.__proxy__ object at 0x1060b5190>), ('date', <django.utils.functional.__proxy__ object at 0x1060b5210>), ('bool', <django.utils.functional.__proxy__ object at 0x1060b5290>), ('object', <django.utils.functional.__proxy__ object at 0x1060b5310>), ('enum', <django.utils.functional.__proxy__ object at 0x1060b5390>))¶
exception DoesNotExist¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist

exception Attribute.MultipleObjectsReturned¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.MultipleObjectsReturned

Attribute.TYPE_BOOLEAN = 'bool'¶
Attribute.TYPE_DATE = 'date'¶
Attribute.TYPE_ENUM = 'enum'¶
Attribute.TYPE_FLOAT = 'float'¶
Attribute.TYPE_INT = 'int'¶
Attribute.TYPE_OBJECT = 'object'¶
Attribute.TYPE_TEXT = 'text'¶
Attribute.clean()[source]¶

Validates the attribute. Will raise ValidationError if the attribute’s datatype is TYPE_ENUM and enum_group is not set, or if the attribute is not TYPE_ENUM and the enum group is set.

Attribute.enum_group¶
Attribute.get_choices()[source]¶

Returns a query set of EnumValue objects for this attribute. Returns None if the datatype of this attribute is not TYPE_ENUM.

Attribute.get_datatype_display(*moreargs, **morekwargs)¶
Attribute.get_next_by_created(*moreargs, **morekwargs)¶
Attribute.get_next_by_modified(*moreargs, **morekwargs)¶
Attribute.get_previous_by_created(*moreargs, **morekwargs)¶
Attribute.get_previous_by_modified(*moreargs, **morekwargs)¶
Attribute.get_validators()[source]¶

Returns the appropriate validator function from validators as a list (of length one) for the datatype.

Note

The reason it returns it as a list, is eventually we may want this method to look elsewhere for additional attribute specific validators to return as well as the default, built-in one.

Attribute.help_text[source]¶
Attribute.objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object at 0x1060b5f50>¶
Attribute.on_site = <django.contrib.sites.managers.CurrentSiteManager object at 0x1060b5f90>¶
Attribute.save(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Saves the Attribute and auto-generates a slug field if one wasn’t provided.

Attribute.save_value(entity, value)[source]¶

Called with entity, any django object registered with eav, and value, the Value this attribute for entity should be set to.

If a Value object for this entity and attribute doesn’t exist, one will be created.

Note

If value is None and a Value object exists for this
Attribute and entity, it will delete that Value object.
Attribute.site¶
Attribute.validate_value(value)[source]¶

Check value against the validators returned by get_validators() for this attribute.

Get all set Value objects for self.model

static post_save_handler(sender, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Post save handler attached to self.model. Calls save() when the model instance we are attached to is saved.

static pre_save_handler(sender, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Pre save handler attached to self.model. Called before the model instance we are attached to is saved. This allows us to call validate_attributes() before the entity is saved.

save()[source]¶

Saves all the EAV values that have been set on this entity.

validate_attributes()[source]¶

Called before save(), first validate all the entity values to make sure they can be created / saved cleanly.

Raise ValidationError if they can’t be.

class eav.models.EnumGroup(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

EnumGroup objects have two fields- a name CharField and enums, a ManyToManyField to EnumValue. Attribute classes with datatype TYPE_ENUM have a ForeignKey field to EnumGroup.

See EnumValue for an example.

exception DoesNotExist¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist

exception EnumGroup.MultipleObjectsReturned¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.MultipleObjectsReturned

EnumGroup.attribute_set¶
EnumGroup.enums¶
EnumGroup.objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object at 0x1060b5090>¶
class eav.models.EnumValue(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

EnumValue objects are the value ‘choices’ to multiple choice TYPE_ENUM Attribute objects.

They have only one field, value, a``CharField`` that must be unique.

For example:

>>> yes = EnumValue.objects.create(value='yes')
>>> no = EnumValue.objects.create(value='no')
>>> unkown = EnumValue.objects.create(value='unkown')

>>> ynu = EnumGroup.objects.create(name='Yes / No / Unkown')
>>> ynu.enums.add(yes, no, unkown)

>>> Atrribute.objects.create(name='Has Fever?',
...                          datatype=Attribute.TYPE_ENUM,
...                          enum_group=ynu)

Note

The same EnumValue objects should be reused within multiple EnumGroups. For example, if you have one EnumGroup called: Yes / No / Unkown and another called Yes / No / Not applicable, you should only have a total of four EnumValues objects, as you should have used the same Yes and No EnumValues for both EnumGroups.

exception DoesNotExist¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist

exception EnumValue.MultipleObjectsReturned¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.MultipleObjectsReturned

EnumValue.eav_values¶
EnumValue.enumgroup_set¶
EnumValue.objects = <django.db.models.manager.Manager object at 0x1060b0610>¶
class eav.models.Value(*args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: django.db.models.base.Model

Putting the V in EAV. This model stores the value for one particular Attribute for some entity.

As with most EAV implementations, most of the columns of this model will be blank, as onle one value_ field will be used.

Example:

>>> import eav
>>> from django.contrib.auth.models import User
>>> eav.register(User)
>>> u = User.objects.create(username='crazy_dev_user')
>>> a = Attribute.objects.create(name='Favorite Drink', datatype='text',
... slug='fav_drink')
>>> Value.objects.create(entity=u, attribute=a, value_text='red bull')
<Value: crazy_dev_user - Favorite Drink: "red bull">
exception DoesNotExist¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.ObjectDoesNotExist

exception Value.MultipleObjectsReturned¶

Bases: django.core.exceptions.MultipleObjectsReturned

Value.attribute¶
Value.clean()[source]¶

Value.entity¶

Provides a generic relation to any object through content-type/object-id fields.

registry¶

This contains the registry classes

Classes¶
class eav.registry.EavConfig[source]¶

Bases: object

The default EevConfig class used if it is not overriden on registration. This is where all the default eav attribute names are defined.

eav_attr = 'eav'¶
generic_relation_attr = 'eav_values'¶
generic_relation_related_name = None¶
classmethod get_attributes()[source]¶

By default, all Attribute object apply to an entity, unless you provide a custom EavConfig class overriding this.

manager_attr = 'objects'¶
manager_only = False¶
class eav.registry.Registry(model_cls)[source]¶

Bases: object

Handles registration through the register() and unregister() methods.

static attach_eav_attr(sender, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Attache EAV Entity toolkit to an instance after init.

static register(model_cls, config_cls=None)[source]¶

Registers model_cls with eav. You can pass an optional config_cls to override the EavConfig defaults.

Note

Multiple registrations for the same entity are harmlessly ignored.

static unregister(model_cls)[source]¶

Unregisters model_cls with eav.

Note

Unregistering a class not already registered is harmlessly ignored.

validators¶

validators¶

This module contains a validator for each Attribute datatype.

A validator is a callable that takes a value and raises a ValidationError if it doesn’t meet some criteria. (see django validators)

These validators are called by the validate_value() method in the Attribute model.

Functions¶
eav.validators.validate_bool(value)[source]¶

Raises ValidationError unless value type is bool

eav.validators.validate_date(value)[source]¶

Raises ValidationError unless value is an instance of datetime or date

eav.validators.validate_enum(value)[source]¶

Raises ValidationError unless value is a saved EnumValue model instance.

eav.validators.validate_float(value)[source]¶

Raises ValidationError unless value can be cast as a float

eav.validators.validate_int(value)[source]¶

Raises ValidationError unless value can be cast as an int

eav.validators.validate_object(value)[source]¶

Raises ValidationError unless value is a saved django model instance.

eav.validators.validate_text(value)[source]¶

Raises ValidationError unless value type is str or unicode

disqus¶

api¶

class disqus.api.DisqusClient(**kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

Client for the DISQUS API.

Example:
>>> client = DisqusClient()
>>> json = client.get_forum_list(user_api_key=DISQUS_API_KEY)
METHODS = {'moderate_post': 'POST', 'thread_by_identifier': 'POST', 'get_user_name': 'POST', 'get_updated_threads': 'GET', 'get_thread_posts': 'GET', 'get_num_posts': 'GET', 'get_thread_by_url': 'GET', 'get_forum_list': 'GET', 'get_forum_posts': 'GET', 'update_thread': 'POST', 'get_thread_list': 'GET', 'create_post': 'POST', 'get_forum_api_key': 'GET'}¶
call(method, **params)[source]¶

Call the DISQUS API and return the json response. URLError is raised when the request failed. DisqusException is raised when the query didn’t succeed.

exception disqus.api.DisqusException[source]¶

Bases: exceptions.Exception

Exception raised for errors with the DISQUS API.

forms¶

get_translation_field_excludes(exclude_languages=None)[source]¶

media¶
patch_translation_field(db_field, field, **kwargs)[source]¶
replace_orig_field(option)[source]¶

Replaces each original field in option that is registered for translation by its translation fields.

Returns a new list with replaced fields. If option contains no registered fields, it is returned unmodified.

>>> print self.trans_opts.fields
('title',)
>>> get_translation_fields(self.trans_opts.fields[0])
['title_de', 'title_en']
>>> self.replace_orig_field(['title', 'url'])
['title_de', 'title_en', 'url']

Note that grouped fields are flattened. We do this because:

  1. They are hard to handle in the jquery-ui tabs implementation
  2. They don’t scale well with more than a few languages
  3. It’s better than not handling them at all (okay that’s weak)
>>> print self.trans_opts.fields
(('title', 'url'), 'email')
>>> get_translation_fields(self.trans_opts.fields[0])
['title_de', 'title_en', 'url_de', 'url_en', 'email_de', 'email_en']
>>> self.replace_orig_field((('title', 'url'), 'email', 'text'))
['title_de', 'title_en', 'url_de', 'url_en', 'email_de', 'email_en', 'text']

media¶

fields¶

class modeltranslation.fields.TranslationField(translated_field, language, *args, **kwargs)[source]¶

Bases: object

The translation field functions as a proxy to the original field which is wrapped.

For every field defined in the model’s TranslationOptions localized versions of that field are added to the model depending on the languages given in settings.LANGUAGES.

If for example there is a model News with a field title which is registered for translation and the settings.LANGUAGES contains the de and en languages, the fields title_de and title_en will be added to the model class. These fields are realized using this descriptor.

The translation field needs to know which language it contains therefore that needs to be specified when the field is created.

get_attname_column()[source]¶
south_field_triple()[source]¶

Returns a suitable description of this field for South.

class modeltranslation.fields.TranslationFieldDescriptor(field, fallback_value=None, fallback_languages=None)[source]¶

Bases: object

A descriptor used for the original translated field.

modeltranslation.fields.create_translation_field(model, field_name, lang)[source]¶

Translation field factory. Returns a TranslationField based on a fieldname and a language.

The list of supported fields can be extended by defining a tuple of field names in the projects settings.py like this:

MODELTRANSLATION_CUSTOM_FIELDS = ('MyField', 'MyOtherField',)

If the class is neither a subclass of fields in SUPPORTED_FIELDS, nor in CUSTOM_FIELDS an ImproperlyConfigured exception will be raised.

modeltranslation.fields.field_factory(baseclass)[source]¶

manager¶

The idea of MultilingualManager is taken from django-linguo by Zach Mathew

https://github.com/zmathew/django-linguo
